ayahs.text:
This verse begins with a divine oath by Mount Tur (Mount Sinai). While the word 'tur' can refer to any mountain in general, 'Al-Tur' specifically refers to the sacred Mount Sinai where Moses received divine communication and spoke directly with Allah. This mountain holds special significance as the place where divine revelation was transmitted to Moses.

The oath by Mount Tur serves as a powerful opening to the surah, invoking the memory of divine communication and the establishment of divine law. This mountain represents the connection between the earthly and heavenly realms, where human messengers receive divine guidance. The reference establishes a connection between the Mosaic tradition and the Quranic message, emphasizing the continuity of divine guidance throughout history.

This verse contains an oath by the written book, most likely referring to the Torah which was written on stone tablets and given to Moses. The Torah was unique among divine revelations in being physically inscribed on tablets, while the Quran was revealed directly to the heart of Muhammad. This distinction highlights different modes of divine revelation throughout history.

The reference to the written book emphasizes the tangible nature of divine guidance and the importance of preserving divine teachings in written form. This oath connects the present revelation with previous scriptures, showing that Allah has consistently provided guidance to humanity through written records that can be preserved and transmitted across generations.

This verse refers to the unfolded parchment, describing the expansive tablets on which the Torah was inscribed. The mention of 'unfolded' or 'spread out' parchment indicates the comprehensive and detailed nature of the divine law that was revealed to Moses. These tablets were spacious enough to contain the essential divine commandments and guidance.

The imagery of unfolded parchment suggests accessibility and clarity of divine guidance. When divine law is 'unfolded' or spread out, it becomes visible and comprehensible to those who seek guidance. This verse emphasizes that divine revelation is not hidden or cryptic but is made clear and accessible to those who approach it with sincere intent to understand and follow divine guidance.

This verse contains an oath by the 'frequented house' (Al-Bayt Al-Ma'mur). Some commentators interpret this as referring to the Kaaba, which is constantly visited by worshippers performing pilgrimage and circumambulation. Others understand it as referring to the celestial house of worship directly above the Kaaba in the seventh heaven, where angels continuously perform worship, as mentioned in prophetic traditions.

A third interpretation suggests this refers to the inhabited world itself, which is populated with diverse creatures and constant activity. This interpretation connects well with the following oath, creating a comprehensive view of creation from the earth to the heavens. The 'frequented house' represents the center of worship and the focal point of spiritual activity, whether on earth or in the heavens.

This verse contains an oath by the raised roof, referring to the sky or heavens above. When read in conjunction with the previous verse about the inhabited house, it creates the imagery of the world as a vast dwelling place with the sky serving as its elevated ceiling. This metaphor presents the earth as humanity's home with the heavens as its protective covering.

The description of the sky as a 'raised roof' emphasizes both its elevation and its function as shelter and protection for life on earth. This oath draws attention to the architectural perfection of creation, where every element serves a specific purpose in maintaining the conditions necessary for life. The raised roof provides both beauty and functionality, demonstrating divine wisdom in cosmic design.

This verse contains an oath by the kindled sea, referring to the ocean in its state of motion and turbulence. The Arabic term suggests a sea that appears to be boiling or surging with waves. This imagery captures the dynamic and powerful nature of oceanic waters, which appear to bubble and surge with constant motion.

The kindled or surging sea represents the dynamic forces of nature that are simultaneously life-giving and potentially destructive. The constant motion of the sea symbolizes the active, living nature of creation where nothing remains static. This oath, like the others in this sequence, draws attention to the signs of divine power visible in the natural world, preparing the listener for the main message about divine judgment and accountability.

This verse declares the conclusion of the preceding oaths, stating that the punishment of your Lord will surely come to pass. This refers to the Day of Judgment and the inevitable divine reckoning that awaits all humanity. The certainty of this event is emphasized by connecting it to the natural phenomena mentioned in the previous oaths, showing that divine justice is as certain as the laws governing creation.

The punishment mentioned here is not arbitrary but represents the natural consequence of rejecting divine guidance and persisting in wrongdoing. Just as the physical laws governing mountains, books, houses, skies, and seas operate with perfect consistency, so too will divine justice be implemented with absolute certainty and precision. This verse establishes that accountability is built into the very fabric of existence.

This verse emphasizes that nothing can prevent or stop the divine punishment when it comes. No power in creation has the ability to halt or deflect divine justice once it has been decreed. This statement reinforces the absolute nature of divine authority and the futility of trying to escape accountability.

The inability of any force to prevent divine judgment provides both warning and comfort. It warns those who persist in wrongdoing that no earthly power can protect them from divine consequences, while it comforts those who suffer injustice by assuring them that ultimate justice cannot be prevented or delayed indefinitely. This verse emphasizes the sovereignty of divine will over all creation.

This verse describes the Day of Judgment when the heavens will shake violently. The imagery of cosmic upheaval emphasizes the magnitude of that day when the entire order of creation will be transformed. The violent shaking of the heavens indicates that even the most stable and elevated parts of creation will be affected by the events of judgment day.

The shaking of the heavens serves as a sign of the awesome power that will be displayed on the Day of Judgment. This cosmic disturbance represents the transition from the current temporary order to the eternal order of the afterlife. The verse prepares believers for the magnitude of that day while warning deniers about the reality they continue to reject.

This verse describes how mountains will move about like clouds on the Day of Judgment. The earth's grip on these massive formations will be released, and they will break apart and float through the air like weightless objects. This imagery demonstrates the complete transformation of physical laws that will occur on that day.

The movement of mountains represents the dissolution of everything that appears permanent and stable in this world. Mountains, which symbolize strength and permanence in human perception, will become as light as clouds, showing that only divine power is truly permanent and unchanging. This transformation serves as a reminder that attachment to worldly stability is misplaced, as all creation is temporary except Allah.

This verse pronounces woe and destruction for the deniers on that day. After describing the cosmic upheavals that will occur, attention turns to the fate of those who rejected divine guidance despite receiving clear warnings. The woe mentioned here represents the comprehensive failure and regret that will befall those who chose denial over faith.

The deniers will face the consequences of their choice to reject truth despite having received adequate guidance and warnings. Their denial was not based on lack of evidence but on their preference for falsehood and their unwillingness to submit to divine authority. This verse serves as both warning and confirmation that choices made in this life have eternal consequences.

This verse describes the deniers as those who engage in frivolous talk and play, remaining heedless of serious spiritual realities. Their life is characterized by involvement in meaningless conversations and activities that distract them from contemplating their ultimate purpose and destiny. They treat life as a game rather than recognizing it as a test and preparation for eternal life.

The characterization of deniers as being engaged in play highlights their fundamental misunderstanding of life's purpose and seriousness. While believers approach life with consciousness of accountability and divine observation, deniers immerse themselves in distractions that prevent spiritual growth and awareness. Their frivolous approach to life reflects their rejection of the serious responsibilities that come with being conscious beings capable of moral choice.

This verse describes how the deniers will be pushed and shoved toward the fire of Hell on the Day of Judgment. The forceful manner of their movement toward punishment contrasts sharply with their previous casual attitude toward divine warnings. They will be compelled to face the reality they had denied and mocked during their worldly life.

The pushing toward Hell represents the inevitable progression from denial to accountability. Those who refused to move voluntarily toward divine guidance in this life will be moved involuntarily toward their consequences in the next. This imagery emphasizes that the choice to respond to divine guidance voluntarily in this life is an opportunity that will not be available in the afterlife.

This verse contains the words that will be spoken to the deniers as they face the fire: 'This is the fire which you used to deny.' The confrontation with reality will make their previous denial appear foolish and inexcusable. They will be forced to acknowledge the truth of what they had rejected, but this acknowledgment will come too late to benefit them.

The reminder of their denial serves to emphasize the justice of their punishment. They are not suffering due to ignorance or lack of opportunity, but because they deliberately chose to reject clear guidance. This verse highlights the principle that divine justice is always preceded by clear warning and adequate opportunity for repentance.

This verse poses a mocking question to the deniers: 'Is this magic, or do you not see?' They had previously dismissed divine warnings as magic or illusion, but now they are confronted with undeniable reality. The question forces them to acknowledge that their previous explanations were inadequate and that they can no longer dismiss what they are experiencing.

The reference to their previous accusations of magic highlights the weakness of their arguments against divine truth. When people cannot refute divine guidance intellectually, they often resort to accusations of deception or supernatural trickery. This verse demonstrates that such accusations will be shown to be baseless when reality becomes undeniable.

This verse instructs the deniers to enter the fire, stating that whether they show patience or impatience makes no difference now. Their crying, complaining, or attempts to maintain composure will not change their situation. The time for choices and their consequences has passed, and they must now experience the results of their decisions.

The indifference to their emotional state emphasizes that the afterlife is a realm of consequences rather than opportunities for change. Unlike worldly life where patience and perseverance can improve circumstances, the afterlife is where accounts are settled based on previous choices. The verse concludes by reminding them that they are only receiving the recompense for what they used to do, emphasizing the justice of their situation.

This verse shifts to describing the blessed state of the righteous, who will be in gardens and bliss. The contrast with the previous descriptions of punishment for deniers highlights the justice of divine recompense, where each group receives exactly what their choices and actions have earned. The gardens represent the flourishing of their spiritual development in eternal form.

The mention of gardens and bliss emphasizes both the beauty and the satisfaction that await those who lived righteously. The gardens suggest growth, life, and beauty, while bliss indicates deep contentment and happiness. These rewards are not arbitrary gifts but the natural result of lives spent in harmony with divine guidance and in service to divine purposes.

This verse describes the righteous as enjoying the bounties that their Lord has given them, while being saved from the punishment of Hell. Their enjoyment is pure and complete because it is free from any fear of loss or punishment. The protection from Hell's torment allows them to fully appreciate and benefit from the divine gifts they receive.

The combination of positive reward and protection from punishment represents the completeness of divine mercy for the righteous. They not only receive good things but are also shielded from harmful consequences. This dual blessing reflects the comprehensive nature of divine care for those who lived in accordance with divine guidance during their worldly existence.

This verse instructs the righteous to eat and drink with satisfaction as a reward for their deeds. The invitation to enjoy divine bounty without restraint represents the ultimate hospitality and generosity. This command reflects divine pleasure with their previous conduct and divine desire for their complete happiness and satisfaction.

The reference to their deeds as the basis for this reward represents divine courtesy and honor toward the righteous, even though their good deeds were enabled by divine grace. The righteous will repeatedly acknowledge that their rewards exceed their merits and represent pure divine favor. This verse demonstrates the generous nature of divine recompense, where rewards far exceed the efforts that earned them.

This verse describes the righteous as reclining on couches arranged in rows, and being married to companions with beautiful eyes (houris). The imagery of reclining suggests comfort, rest, and dignity, while the orderly arrangement indicates the harmonious and organized nature of paradise. The companionship represents the social and emotional fulfillment that awaits the righteous.

The marriage to houris represents the perfect companionship and intimate joy that will be available to the righteous. These relationships will be characterized by beauty, purity, and perfect compatibility, providing emotional and spiritual satisfaction that complements the physical comforts of paradise. This verse addresses the complete range of human needs and desires, showing that paradise provides fulfillment on every level.

This verse explains that believers whose offspring followed them in faith will be reunited with their righteous descendants in paradise. Even if the children's level of righteousness was lower than their parents', they will be elevated to join their parents in higher levels of paradise. This represents divine generosity and consideration for family bonds and the desire of parents for their children's welfare.

The reunion of believing families in paradise demonstrates divine mercy that extends beyond individual merit to consider family relationships and emotional bonds. Parents who spent their lives working for their children's spiritual welfare will not be separated from them in the afterlife if the children maintained even basic faith and righteousness. The verse concludes by emphasizing that this divine favor does not diminish the rewards of those who earned higher levels through their superior deeds.

This verse states that the righteous will be continuously supplied with fruits and meat according to their desires. The ongoing provision represents the abundance and variety of sustenance available in paradise, where every preference will be satisfied without limitation or exhaustion of supply. The divine commitment to continuous provision ensures that satisfaction will never be threatened by scarcity.

The variety of foods mentioned indicates that paradise will cater to every taste and preference, providing not just basic sustenance but culinary pleasure and satisfaction. The ability to have whatever they desire shows that the restrictive aspects of worldly life, where desires often exceed means, will be completely removed in paradise. This verse emphasizes the generosity and thoughtfulness of divine hospitality toward the righteous.

This verse describes the righteous as playfully taking cups from one another in paradise, containing a drink that causes no empty talk or sinful behavior. This imagery shows the joyful and social nature of paradise, where the righteous will enjoy friendly gatherings and celebrations. The playful interaction demonstrates the complete absence of negative emotions or competitive harmful behavior.

The drink of paradise will provide joy and celebration without the negative side effects associated with worldly intoxicants. Unlike earthly drinks that can lead to loss of reason or immoral behavior, the drinks of paradise will enhance happiness while maintaining dignity and moral awareness. This perfect balance represents the superior nature of divine gifts that provide pleasure without harmful consequences.

This verse describes the young men who will serve the righteous in paradise, comparing them to pearls hidden in their shells. The imagery suggests both beauty and purity, with the servants appearing as precious and unblemished as perfectly preserved pearls. Their service represents the honor and dignity with which the righteous will be treated in paradise.

The comparison to hidden pearls emphasizes the exceptional beauty and value of these servants, who will provide perfect service without any deficiency or displeasure. Their presence adds to the overall atmosphere of luxury and comfort in paradise, while their pearl-like quality suggests that even the servants in paradise exceed worldly standards of beauty and perfection.

This verse describes how the righteous in paradise will turn to one another and engage in conversation. The social interaction in paradise will be characterized by mutual interest, kindness, and meaningful communication. Unlike worldly conversations that can involve conflict or superficiality, the discussions in paradise will be marked by genuine care and spiritual enrichment.

The emphasis on mutual conversation highlights the social nature of human happiness and the importance of companionship in complete fulfillment. The righteous will not only enjoy individual pleasures but will also share their experiences and gratitude with others, creating a community of mutual appreciation and joy that enhances everyone's happiness.

This verse records the righteous saying that they used to live among their families in fear and anxiety during their worldly life. Despite living normal family lives, they were constantly concerned about the acceptability of their worship and the sincerity of their intentions. They worried about whether their good deeds would be accepted and whether they might commit errors that would nullify their efforts.

This constant spiritual anxiety reflects the deep awareness of divine accountability that characterized their worldly existence. They understood the serious nature of their spiritual responsibilities and the possibility of falling short of divine standards. Their fear was not based on despair but on humility and recognition of their dependence on divine mercy for salvation.

This verse continues their conversation, acknowledging that Allah bestowed His favor upon them and saved them from the punishment of the scorching fire. They recognize that their salvation was due to divine grace rather than their own merit, despite their sincere efforts and constant vigilance. Their protection from punishment represents the successful outcome of their spiritual anxiety and striving.

The acknowledgment of divine favor demonstrates the humility and gratitude that will characterize the righteous in paradise. Even after receiving confirmation of their salvation, they will continue to attribute their success to divine mercy rather than personal achievement. This attitude reflects the spiritual maturity that developed during their worldly struggles with fear and hope.

This verse records their acknowledgment that they used to call upon Allah regularly in their worldly life, recognizing Him as the Most Kind and Most Merciful. Their consistent prayer and supplication during their earthly existence reflected their recognition of their dependence on divine mercy and their hope for divine forgiveness and guidance.

The regular calling upon Allah represents the spiritual practice that sustained them through their anxieties and struggles. Their recognition of divine kindness and mercy provided them with hope and motivation to continue striving despite their fears of inadequacy. This verse emphasizes the importance of maintaining connection with Allah through prayer and remembrance as the foundation of spiritual development.

This verse commands the Prophet to continue giving reminders, affirming that he is neither a soothsayer nor a madman by the grace of his Lord. The command addresses both the Prophet's mission and the false accusations made against him by his opponents. The continuation of the reminder is emphasized despite the opposition and mockery he faces.

The denial of being a soothsayer or madman directly refutes the common accusations made by those who rejected his message. These accusations were attempts to discredit his prophetic mission by attributing his knowledge to supernatural sources other than divine revelation or by suggesting mental instability. The verse affirms that his guidance comes from divine grace and represents genuine prophetic wisdom rather than fortune-telling or delusion.

This verse questions whether the disbelievers claim that the Prophet is merely a poet for whom they are waiting to see the vicissitudes of time. The Meccan polytheists would console themselves by suggesting that Muhammad was just a poet whose influence would eventually fade with changing circumstances. They adopted a 'wait and see' attitude, expecting his movement to collapse naturally.

The reference to waiting for the vicissitudes of time reflects their assumption that the Prophet's message was a temporary phenomenon that would be overcome by changing political or social circumstances. They hoped that patience would vindicate their rejection of his message without requiring them to engage seriously with its content or implications.

This verse instructs the Prophet to tell them to wait, as he too will wait with them. This response turns their challenge back upon them, creating a mutual test of whose expectations will be vindicated by future events. The Prophet's confidence in divine support allows him to accept their challenge calmly.

The mutual waiting creates a situation where time itself becomes the arbiter between truth and falsehood. Rather than being intimidated by their threats or challenges, the Prophet expresses confidence that time will reveal the truth of his message and the falsity of their claims. This response demonstrates the calm assurance that comes from relying on divine support rather than human power.

This verse questions whether their intellects are teaching them to make such claims, or whether they are simply a rebellious people. The question addresses the source of their rejection of divine guidance, asking whether it stems from rational analysis or from stubborn opposition to truth. The implication is that their rejection is based on rebellion rather than reason.

The reference to their intellects ironically points out that rational consideration would lead to acceptance of the Prophet's message rather than rejection. Their continued denial despite clear evidence indicates that their opposition is driven by arrogance, stubbornness, and unwillingness to submit to divine authority rather than by genuine intellectual difficulties with the message.

This verse asks whether they claim that the Prophet has fabricated the Quran himself through deliberate effort and composition. The Arabic term suggests the accusation that he created the message through careful labor and artifice rather than receiving it through divine revelation. The verse concludes that the real issue is their unwillingness to believe rather than any problem with the message itself.

The accusation of fabrication represents their attempt to explain the Quran's remarkable qualities without acknowledging its divine origin. However, their inability to produce anything similar, despite the challenge to do so, demonstrates the inadequacy of this explanation. Their continued rejection reveals that the problem lies in their hearts rather than in the evidence presented to them.

This verse challenges them to produce a discourse similar to the Quran if they are truthful in claiming that it is merely human composition. This challenge has been repeatedly offered throughout the Quran, inviting them to demonstrate their claim by matching its literary excellence, wisdom, and comprehensiveness.

The challenge to produce similar discourse represents a test of their accusations. If the Quran is merely human composition, as they claim, then they should be able to create something comparable using their own literary talents and cultural knowledge. Their failure to meet this challenge, despite having accomplished poets and orators among them, demonstrates the unique nature of the Quranic revelation.

This verse poses fundamental philosophical questions: were they created from nothing, or are they themselves the creators? These questions address the basic issue of existence and causation that underlies belief in divine authority. The questions are designed to lead them to recognize the logical necessity of a Creator.

The impossibility of self-creation or creation from nothing leads logically to the recognition that they must have been created by another being. This philosophical argument demonstrates that belief in a Creator is not merely religious sentiment but rational necessity. Their rejection of divine authority becomes illogical when they cannot provide alternative explanations for their own existence.

This verse continues the logical questioning by asking whether they created the heavens and the earth. The extension of the argument from personal existence to cosmic creation emphasizes the comprehensive nature of divine creativity and power. The verse concludes that they simply lack certainty and conviction about these fundamental truths.

The inability to claim creation of the heavens and earth further demonstrates the weakness of their position in rejecting divine authority. If they acknowledge that they did not create themselves or the universe, logic demands recognition of the Creator who did. Their lack of certainty represents a spiritual and intellectual condition that prevents them from accepting clear rational conclusions.

This verse asks whether they possess the treasures of divine mercy or whether they are the controllers of divine affairs. The questions address their presumption in judging divine choices, particularly their criticism of the Prophet's selection for his mission. They had objected that divine revelation should have been sent to someone of higher social status or wealth.

The reference to divine treasures and control highlights their lack of authority over divine decisions about revelation and guidance. Their objections to divine choices reveal their assumption that they are qualified to judge divine wisdom and determine who should receive divine favor. This presumption demonstrates their fundamental misunderstanding of the relationship between Creator and creation.

This verse questions whether they have a ladder to the heavens that allows them to listen to divine communications. The imagery suggests the impossibility of their accessing divine knowledge through their own means, making their claims about divine matters unfounded. If they had such access, they should be able to provide clear evidence.

The challenge for evidence of their supposed access to divine knowledge exposes the baseless nature of their claims about spiritual realities. Unlike the Prophet, who receives revelation through divine choice and provides clear signs of his prophetic mission, they have no evidence for their alternative explanations of spiritual phenomena.

This verse questions their attribution of daughters to Allah while claiming sons for themselves. This addresses their practice of assigning female offspring to Allah while preferring male children for themselves, revealing the inconsistency and unfairness of their beliefs about divine nature and their own preferences.

The contradiction in their gender preferences exposes the illogical nature of their polytheistic beliefs and their presumption in attributing human characteristics and preferences to Allah. Their assignment of what they consider less desirable (daughters) to Allah while keeping what they prefer (sons) for themselves demonstrates both their misunderstanding of divine nature and their lack of respect for divine majesty.

This verse asks whether the Prophet is demanding payment from them, making them feel burdened by debt. The question highlights the purely altruistic nature of the prophetic mission, which seeks no worldly compensation or benefit. The Prophet's message is offered freely without any financial obligation or material exchange.

The absence of any payment demand removes one possible motive for rejecting the message. Since the Prophet seeks no worldly benefit from his mission, their opposition cannot be justified as resistance to exploitation or personal gain. This demonstrates the pure spiritual nature of his calling and eliminates material considerations as factors in evaluating his message.

This verse questions whether they possess knowledge of the unseen which they are recording. The claim to knowledge of unseen realities would require extraordinary evidence and authority that they clearly do not possess. Their pronouncements about spiritual matters lack the divine authorization that characterizes genuine prophetic knowledge.

The absence of genuine knowledge of the unseen exposes the baseless nature of their alternative explanations for prophetic claims and spiritual realities. Unlike the Prophet, who demonstrates access to divine knowledge through accurate predictions and profound insights, they have no evidence of supernatural knowledge that would qualify them to make authoritative statements about spiritual matters.

This verse questions whether they intend to scheme against divine guidance, pointing out that disbelievers ultimately become victims of their own plotting. Their plans to discredit the Prophet and prevent the spread of his message will ultimately rebound against them. Their schemes are based on false premises and will fail when confronted with divine support for truth.

The self-defeating nature of schemes against divine guidance reflects the principle that opposition to truth ultimately harms those who engage in it. While they may temporarily appear to succeed in creating obstacles or spreading confusion, their efforts will eventually be exposed as futile and their own spiritual condition will suffer from their deliberate opposition to clear guidance.

This verse questions whether they have any deity other than Allah, declaring Allah's transcendence above the partnership they attribute to Him. The question exposes the inadequacy of their alternative objects of worship and the logical inconsistency of their polytheistic beliefs. True divinity requires qualities that only Allah possesses.

The declaration of divine transcendence above their polytheistic practices emphasizes the purity and uniqueness of true divine nature. Their attribution of partners to Allah represents a fundamental misunderstanding of divine attributes and a degradation of the concept of divinity. This verse affirms the absolute monotheism that underlies proper understanding of divine reality.

This verse describes their attitude toward divine punishment, stating that even if they saw pieces of the sky falling, they would claim it was merely piled-up clouds. Their denial would persist even in the face of obvious supernatural intervention, demonstrating the extent of their stubborn refusal to acknowledge divine power.

The reference to calling falling sky fragments 'piled-up clouds' parallels the reaction of the people of 'Ad, who saw approaching divine punishment as beneficial rain clouds. This persistent misinterpretation of clear signs shows how denial can become so entrenched that even dramatic evidence fails to produce recognition of divine intervention.

This verse instructs the Prophet to leave them alone until they encounter their day when they will be struck down. The command to 'leave them' appears frequently in early Meccan revelations, indicating that after clear guidance has been offered and rejected, divine wisdom allows people to continue in their chosen path until they face the consequences.

The reference to their appointed day emphasizes that divine justice operates according to divine timing rather than human expectations. The instruction to leave them alone does not indicate divine indifference but rather represents divine patience combined with certainty that justice will ultimately be served when the appointed time arrives.

This verse describes the day when their schemes will be of no benefit to them and they will receive no help from any source. All the plots and strategies they used to oppose divine guidance will prove completely ineffective when they face divine judgment. Their supporters and allies will be unable to provide any assistance.

The failure of their schemes and the absence of help emphasize the complete reversal of power relationships that will occur on the Day of Judgment. Those who appeared strong and clever in worldly life will find themselves powerless and abandoned, while those who relied on divine guidance will receive divine support and protection.

This verse states that the wrongdoers will face punishment before the final judgment, though most of them do not realize this. This earlier punishment may refer to the famine that afflicted Mecca or the defeat at the Battle of Badr, where many Meccan leaders were killed. These preliminary punishments serve as warnings and previews of greater consequences to come.

The ignorance of most wrongdoers about their impending punishment reflects their spiritual blindness and their assumption that the absence of immediate consequences indicates the absence of divine accountability. They fail to recognize that divine justice operates on multiple levels and timelines, with worldly consequences often preceding final judgment.

This verse commands the Prophet to be patient for the judgment of his Lord, assuring him that he is under divine observation and protection. The command to patience appears frequently in early Meccan revelations, providing encouragement during the difficult period of opposition and persecution. Divine observation ensures that his struggles are witnessed and his efforts are valued.

The assurance of being under divine sight provides comfort and strength during times of trial and opposition. The Prophet's patience is not passive waiting but active perseverance in his mission despite obstacles and hostility. This divine support enables him to continue his work with confidence and determination.

This verse instructs the Prophet to glorify Allah with praise when he rises, referring particularly to the night prayer (tahajjud) that was emphasized in the early period of Islam. The command also includes glorifying Allah during parts of the night, establishing the spiritual practices that would later become the formal prayer times.

The emphasis on night worship reflects the special value of voluntary devotion performed when there are fewer distractions and the soul is more receptive to spiritual influence. These night prayers provide spiritual strength and divine connection that sustain the Prophet through the challenges of his mission. The mention of rising suggests both awakening for prayer and standing in worship.
